_data.description: Making content full bleed (no matter its parent width)
_data.title: Make an element span the full screen width

children.value: Rarely will your webpage span the full width—most of the time, you'll apply some rule like
. Sometimes, you'll want to "break out" of that and allow child elements to exceed their parent width. The rules above, applied to some child element you want to be full bleed, will do just that.

_data.description: Using box-decoration-break to prevent abrupt style interruptions
_data.title: Make CSS styling span multiple lines

children.value: Prevents styling applied to text to break abruptly at the end of a line. The above will force it to 'finish' its style (e.g., round a border and finish padding) at the end of the line, and start again at the next line.

props.style: background: steelblue; color: white; padding: 1px 3px; border-radius: 5px;

children.value: Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum

props.style: box-decoration-break: clone; background: steelblue; color: white; padding: 1px 3px; border-radius: 5px;

children.value: Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum

_data.text: ```css -webkit-box-decoration-break: clone; box-decoration-break: clone; ``` # Context Prevents styling applied to text to break abruptly at the end of a line. The above will force it to 'finish' its style (e.g., round a border and finish padding) at the end of the line, and start again at the next line. An example **without**: Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum An example **with**: Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum

_data.description: Format all files with a given extension using Prettier on the command line.
_data.title: Format all files using Prettier

children.value: on all files in a given directory, and your VSCode extension isn't working (thanks M1?).
matches the file extension you want to target and format.

_data.text:
```shell
prettier --write "**/*.vue"
```

# Context 

When you want to run `prettier` on all files in a given directory, and your VSCode extension isn't working (thanks M1?).

Where `.vue` matches the file extension you want to target and format.

_data.description: For when you've already started a project and want to start VC late
_data.title: Initialize a Git Repository from an Existing Project

children.value: your project with git initialized/version control set up, you want to do so in an existing directory.

_data.text:
```shell
git init
git add .
git commit -m "init"

## Setup on GitHub/GitLab, etc.
git remote add origin git@github.com:<username/new_repo>
git push -u origin master
```

# Context 

Super simple. Basically, rather than *begin* your project with git initialized/version control set up, you want to do so in an existing directory.

_data.description: Please don't let your content span the full page width
_data.title: Style your webpage with one rule

children.value: Webpages aren't pretty by default. The above will make a readable, single column in the center of the screen.

_data.description: Apply scroll padding to your entire webpage
_data.title: Prevent fixed navbar from overlapping hash-navigated content

children.value: When your navbar is fixed (e.g. attached to the top of the webpage at all times), it takes up no space on the page. This means that it overlaps content below it; when navigating to subsections on your webpage, e.g. through hash-navigation, this means that the content below the navbar will be obscured.
fixes this problem. As explained on Web Platform News:

For example, websites with sticky headers can apply a matching scroll padding to the top of the page to ensure that scroll targets (e.g., section headings) aren’t concealed by the header after certain scroll operations (anchor scrolling, scrollIntoView method, etc.).

_data.text:
```css
html {
  scroll-padding-top: 70px; /* height of sticky header */
}
```

# Context 

When your navbar is fixed (e.g. attached to the top of the webpage at all times), it takes up no space on the page. This means that it overlaps content below it; when navigating to subsections on your webpage, e.g. through hash-navigation, this means that the content below the navbar will be obscured.

`scroll-padding-top` fixes this problem. As explained on Web Platform News:

> For example, websites with sticky headers can apply a matching scroll padding to the top of the page to ensure that scroll targets (e.g., section headings) aren’t concealed by the header after certain scroll operations (anchor scrolling, scrollIntoView method, etc.).

_data.description: Untrack files already added to git repository based on .gitignore
_data.title: Untrack tracked files

children.value: just to visit GitHub/Lab and realize its still there? It was probably never untracked. Doing the above will remove all files from git, readd them (with the newly ignored file), and recommit.

_data.text:
```bash
git rm -r --cached .
git add .
git commit -m ".gitignore fix"
```

# Context 

Ever added a file to `.gitignore` just to visit GitHub/Lab and realize its still there? It was probably never untracked. Doing the above will remove all files from git, readd them (with the newly ignored file), and recommit.
